newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan military on alert over new year holidays.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan military on alert over new year holidays.

text.p: Taiwan's armed forces were on routine alert against surprise attacks by "the enemy" -- communist China -- as the island began celebrating the five-day Lunar New Year holiday on Thursday, state radio said.

"As families gather to celebrate the Lunar New Year, the national armed forces sacrifice their holidays to stay on high alert," the broadcast said. "The preparation is aimed at effectively deterring the enemy's attempt to attack Taiwan."
The radio quoted Defence Minister Chiang Chung-ling as saying the unspecified enemy was mostly likely to attack at the time of important holidays.

Taiwan's only security threat, China, has regarded the Nationalist-ruled island as a rebel province since a civil war separated them in 1949 and regularly pledges to retake Taiwan by force if it declares independence.

In mid-1995, China mounted eight months of war games and missile tests near Taiwan and clamped a freeze on what had been slowly warming unofficial talks with Taiwan after President Lee Teng-hui's private visit to the United States.
Beijing interpreted Lee's trip as a bid to promote Taiwan's independence. Taipei denies Beijing's allegations that it has secretly abandoned its advocacy of eventual reunification.
